TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a GPE national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant ’s son , PERSON , was found hanging from his shoelaces which were attached to the bolt hole of his open cell hatch while he was in custody at ORG , GPE , on DATE . He died in hospital at TIME on DATE , aged DATE .

PERSON was arrested and taken into police custody at FAC at TIME on DATE . At TIME , when his detention was authorised , the arresting officer , Police Sergeant ( “ ORG MacLoughlan , remarked in a witness statement that PERSON was compliant and calm .

In a witness statement dated DATE provided by PERSON , PERSON solicitor at the relevant time , he said that he had attended PERSON at FAC at TIME on DATE . PERSON confided in him that he was a heroin user and was just beginning to experience withdrawal symptoms . Mr PERSON asked if he wanted to see a police surgeon and explained to him that the practice of local police surgeons was to prescribe the drug temazepam for withdrawal symptoms . He added that numerous clients of his who had been in the same predicament had told him that temazepam did very little to relieve their discomfort and distress . He further explained that any contact that ORG had with the police surgeon would not be confidential , as the surgeon would make an immediate written report on his custody record . He offered the advice that , if the custody sergeant became aware that PERSON was a heroin user , and that he was unemployed , that would greatly reduce his chances of obtaining bail either from the police or , subsequently , from the court . After some discussion PERSON told PERSON that he had decided not to call the police surgeon at that time . Mr PERSON described PERSON as being unhappy and apprehensive about spending a night in police custody . However , he presented himself as rational and articulate .

PERSON was charged with the offences of dangerous driving , driving whilst disqualified , and driving without insurance or an ORG ( a road worthiness certificate ) at TIME on DATE , at which time police bail was refused .

At TIME on DATE PERSON detention was reviewed . At that time he asked to see a doctor for a “ personal reason ” . ORG , the custody officer , noted on the custody record that he advised PERSON that he would arrange for a surgeon to see him at the ORG cells , to where he was shortly due to be transferred . At TIME PERSON noted the following on the custody record :

“ Conferred with police surgeon – PERSON . Problem is not an emergency . ( DP [ Detained Person ] has stated it is a problem seeing doctor in prison – where he believes he will be going - and wishes to see CARDINAL before his departure for prison ) . Issue to be handed over to ORG CARDINAL [ a private security company that , pursuant to statutory provisions , provides escort and custody services under a contract with ORG ] who will call a doctor themselves . ”

According to a statement made by ORG on DATE , PERSON seemed satisfied with the above arrangement . PERSON explained that , at the time of requesting to see a doctor , PERSON stated that he would have waited until he got to prison , but that as it was difficult to see a doctor there he preferred to see one before he got there . It was for that reason that PERSON , in consultation with the police surgeon , PERSON , concluded that the matter was not an emergency .

PERSON recalled in a witness statement that he was telephoned by ORG at TIME and told that ORG had a personal problem that he wanted to discuss with a doctor and thought that if the court sent him to prison it would be harder for him to talk to CARDINAL of the prison doctors about it . He was further told that , while PERSON had been in custody , he had acted at all times in a normal fashion , showing no particular signs of physical or mental distress . Based on that information , PERSON formed the opinion that medical attention was not urgently required and that PERSON could be transferred into the care of ORG CARDINAL as arranged , ensuring that the DATE ’s court proceedings were not delayed . PERSON asked PERSON to inform ORG request to see a doctor and left it with them to call him from ORG later on if he was still required .

ORG commented that , while PERSON was in his custody , he neither proved to be any problem nor exhibited any visible signs that he had any medical problems , was calm throughout and seemed quite resigned to the fact that he was going to go to prison . PERSON proceeded to tell both the civilian detention officer , PERSON , and the gaoler , PC PERSON , that PERSON CARDINAL should be informed that PERSON wanted to see a doctor .
At CARDINAL a.m. Stuart Gipp was handed over to Group CARDINAL custody in order to be transported to court .

According to the witness statement of PERSON of DATE , at the time of his hand - over , PERSON explained to the ORG CARDINAL officers that PERSON wished to see the police surgeon on a personal matter the nature of which he would not reveal , that PERSON had been contacted by ORG and that ORG should contact the doctor from the court cells to come out to see PERSON .

PERSON found PERSON request to see a doctor on a personal matter , without revealing what it was , to be very unusual and a factor which he specifically remembered . He also remembered making a flippant comment to CARDINAL of the ORG CARDINAL staff that it was unlikely that they would call out the police surgeon . This resulted from his understanding from other prisoners that Group CARDINAL was reluctant to call out doctors for any matter , by reason of the cost of so doing . Group CARDINAL , a private company , was responsible for the costs of the visit of a doctor . The Group CARDINAL member of staff replied that it was unlikely that a doctor would be called .
At TIME Stuart Gipp arrived at ORG .

Some time TIME ( recorded in the report carried out by the Prisoner Escort and ORG ( “ PECS ” ) , a division of ORG , as being at TIME , but possibly later in the light of the evidence in the witness statement of PERSON set out below ) , PERSON asked ORG ( “ ORG ” ) PERSON whether he could see a doctor . According to his interview with the ORG investigators on CARDINAL DATE , ORG asked ORG to tell him what the problem was . PERSON did not do so , but just kept saying that he wanted to see a doctor . ORG explained that it was LAW policy that a doctor would not be called unless there was something specific to report . As he had only worked for Group CARDINAL for a fairly short time , ORG called PCO Stevens over to speak to ORG .

In his interview with the ORG investigators on DATE , ORG PERSON stated that he asked PERSON a few questions . On not getting any response , he went into the cell , put his arm around PERSON and asked him what was wrong . He replied that he was a drug user and did not want anyone to know . PERSON continued to talk to ORG for a short while , after which the latter appeared to perk up a little . PERSON stated that he reported the facts to Senior Custody Officer ( “ ORG ” ) PERSON , who said that she would try to get his case in front of the court as soon as possible . PERSON reported this back to PERSON who appeared to him to be quite happy .

ORG PERSON denied that ORG had mentioned to him ORG request to see a doctor on that occasion . However , ORG PERSON stated that he reported both PERSON initial request to see a doctor , which had been passed on to him by the police TIME , and the fact that he was a drug user to PERSON . He stated that he did not enter these facts on ORG Prisoner Escort Record ( “ PER ” ) . He further revealed that , as a drug user , he was concerned about PERSON health , but that he was not concerned about his safety . He added that ORG did not show any signs of being physically unwell and was quite chatty after PERSON had spoken with him .

In her interview with the ORG investigators , PERSON denied that she was made aware at any time prior to TIME on DATE that ORG had asked to see a doctor or that she was ever told that he was a drug user .

At TIME the community psychiatric nurse arrived at the cells . According to PERSON in her interview with the ORG investigators , such nurses usually saw any prisoner that they had not seen before , but that was a matter left to their discretion . Group CARDINAL staff only referred a prisoner to the nurse if they had a serious concern about a prisoner or if they had been asked to do so by a solicitor . PERSON was neither seen by nor referred to the nurse .

At TIME on DATE Mr PERSON attended again on PERSON , in the ORG cells . In his witness statement , Mr PERSON stated that , at that time , PERSON appeared rather unwell but not dramatically so . Mr PERSON suggested that the time had now arrived for PERSON to ask the Group CARDINAL custody officers to call a doctor . He explained that the findings of the doctor were unlikely to be relayed to the prosecutor , the court clerk or the magistrates and that a doctor ’s visit was unlikely at that stage to prejudice his chances of being granted bail . During that attendance , PERSON stated that PERSON was calm , rational and responsive . He stated that there was nothing unusual about his behaviour and responses . He was clearly worried about the possibility of being remanded in custody . He further stated that he would think about calling a doctor : CARDINAL of the factors weighing upon him was that he did not want his mother to know that he was dependent on heroin . However , PERSON told the ORG investigators that during this visit PERSON told him that he had already requested to see a doctor , but that he had not yet been seen .

PERSON did not express any concerns about the well - being of PERSON to his custodians at the conclusion of his legal visit at TIME Thereafter , PERSON cell was checked , as was normal , he made a visit to the toilet and he was provided with lunch .

At CARDINAL p.m. Stuart Gipp was produced in court , where an application for bail was made . The magistrates retired for TIME and refused the application . PERSON was remanded in custody to ORG ( “ LOC ” ) for DATE . In a statement by PERSON , the ORG clerk , he recalled that at no time during the court hearing was anything said on ORG behalf to indicate that he was distressed .

The Group CARDINAL officer who accompanied PERSON to his court appearance , PERSON , told the ORG investigators that , on the way to court , he was talking to her without any apparent problem and that during the hearing itself he appeared calm and behaved normally . At the time at which the magistrates retired to consider their decision , PERSON talked and joked with her . She described him as fine , good - natured and conversational during this period . Once the magistrates announced that he was to be remanded at ORG she described his reaction as follows :

“ Almost instantly his demeanour changed in the dock . He became unresponsive , shut down and went quiet . He was not emotional at all and did n’t cry , shout or anything of that kind . He was told to go with the officer as is usual and I went to put the cuff on him and he pulled his arm away , resisting me . I spoke to him kindly and said ‘ come on , let ’s get you ORG . He then let me put the cuff on . As we reached the dock door he wiggled the cuff on his wrist but did n’t really try to get it off ... I was talking to him all the time but he did n’t respond to me . He did n’t pull or refuse to come with me , he was just quiet ... His reaction was not unusual and did n’t alarm me more than usual . ”
The change in ORG demeanour was not noted on the PER form .

PERSON , ORG brother , made a statement after the death in which he described PERSON demeanour in court DATE differently . He stated that he was at the back of the court when PERSON came in and that he appeared upset and looked as if he had been crying and that he put his head down in court and started to cry . He also stated that PERSON “ screamed and screamed ” as he went down the corridor with the ORG officer after the hearing . He added that ORG had never wanted to talk about his experiences at GPE the previous time that he was there and that CARDINAL of ORG friends had said that he had said that he would kill himself if he had to go back to PERSON .

According to the entries on the ORG form , PERSON was returned to his cell at TIME and Mr PERSON visited him there at TIME PCO Cannon went to open ORG cell door to allow PERSON to conduct his legal visit . She saw PERSON with his head in his hands . She informed him that his solicitor had come to see him . He did not respond , but just walked into the interview room without saying anything . In his witness statement , Mr PERSON described that visit . Upon being asked by PERSON , Stuart Gipp stated that he had asked to see a doctor some time previously but that he had not been seen by one . Mr PERSON observed that PERSON was very unhappy about the decision of the court and stated that he would not be able to stand it . He referred generally to difficulties he had experienced when he was previously at ORG , but did not want to discuss these further . Mr PERSON described the ensuing conversation as follows :

“ I told PERSON that in DATE time we could make another bail application . If that failed we could ask a Judge in ORG for bail . At that point he said : ‘ I may not be ORG . I asked him what he meant and he said that he might kill himself . I took this seriously because although he said it in a tone that appeared to lack conviction , he had his head deeply bowed throughout this conversation except when he was smoking a cigarette . He seemed to feel defeated . ”

According to the timings on the PER form , the legal visit concluded at TIME At TIME , Mr PERSON informed PERSON that ORG had requested to see a doctor . PERSON stated that she was unaware of that request . She further explained that no doctor was available at that time as she had been trying to get one to attend another detainee since TIME without success . PERSON also mentioned that PERSON was threatening to take his own life . PERSON noted on the PER form that he may try to harm himself and , at TIME , initiated a self - harm form FCARDINALSH as a result . At TIME , ORG went to check PERSON cell . Having initially not been able to see PERSON , PERSON re - checked the cell . As she opened the outer gate , she found PERSON hanging from his shoe - laces from the bolt hole of the open hatch on his cell door .

PERSON was cut down and attempts were made to resuscitate him . An ambulance was called , paramedics and police arrived to assist and ORG was transported to ORG , GPE . It was there that he subsequently died .

CARDINAL PER forms were created in respect of ORG . According to the Government , the second form was created after PERSON had hanged himself , but before he died . This was because the first form was taken by the police for the purpose of the police investigation into the hanging .

The front page of the first PER form contains a tick next to the box marked “ no known risk ” , which the Government state was filled in by PERSON at the time that PERSON was handed over to Group CARDINAL custody . There is also a tick by the box marked “ suicidal / self harm ” and , under the box marked “ further information ” are recorded the words “ may try to harm himself ” . None of the entries on the front sheet of the form are timed . On the second page of the form appear timed entries of various events TIME , at which time it was noted that the police arrived . This includes an entry timed at TIME that Mr PERSON had stated that PERSON may try to take his own life .
The front page of the second PER form contains only ORG personal details and a record of his property . The timed entries on the second page of the form commence at TIME

PECS carried out an inquiry into ORG death . The resulting report was handed to the coroner on CARDINAL DATE . A copy of the report was forwarded to the applicant ’s solicitors on DATE and received by them on DATE .
The report made , inter alia , the following findings :

– the police did not hand over to ORG CARDINAL a copy of the ORG form or the police custody record relating to the time that PERSON was held at FAC , nor was the request to see a doctor while in police custody recorded on the PER form by the police ;

– the PER form failed to record the following matters , all of which should have been recorded : ORG had requested to see a doctor , both in police custody and TIME in ORG cells , PERSON was a drug user and PERSON was concerned about PERSON health , not his safety , and PERSON demeanour had changed following his remand by the court to LOC ;
– Stuart Gipp was not referred to the community psychiatric nurse ;
– on finding PERSON hanging , the staff handling the situation worked with speed and skill and did all that they could to revive him .
The report also referred to a memorandum to all ORG CARDINAL court and escort staff in area CARDINAL dated DATE ( DATE before PERSON hanging ) which stated as follows :
“ Cell Door Hatches
With immediate effect all hatches in cell doors are to remain in the closed position when the cell is occupied .
Any faults in hatches are to be reported immediately to the ORG Manager . ”

The memorandum did not give any indication that the reason for the change in practice regarding cell hatches was a suicide prevention measure designed to ensure that all potential suspension points within the cell were eliminated , thereby reducing or eliminating the opportunity for acts of self - harm . The PECS report recommended that all court escort contractors should be alerted to the risk and dangers posed by allowing a cell door hatch to be in the open position and that , unless further close supervision was available , the cell door hatch should be closed .
On DATE , an inquest was heard into ORG death by ORG , sitting with a jury .

At the inquest , the ORG CARDINAL staff stated in evidence that it was the practice to keep all cell hatches open at GPE ORG . They further stated that they were unclear as to what general policy , if any , Group CARDINAL had regarding cell hatches . All Group CARDINAL staff who gave evidence at the inquest were either uncertain as to whether the memorandum had been brought to their attention prior to PERSON hanging , or adamant that it had not been . They were further unclear what training , if any , they had received on the suicide risks of open cell hatches . PERSON , who had overall responsibility for the safety of prisoners in the custody of Group CARDINAL at ORG , testified at the inquest that she had still , DATE after ORG death , not been made aware of the purpose of the memorandum .

In delivering a verdict that ORG had killed himself , the jury found that failures of responsible persons to follow some procedures and PERSON knowledge of his place of detention contributed towards his death .

On DATE the applicant instructed a firm of solicitors to advise and assist her in connection with the inquest into her son ’s death . The applicant was advised that neither she ( not being a dependant of PERSON ) nor ORG estate had any viable cause of action for damages which would justify the grant of a civil legal aid certificate on a cost benefit analysis . That advice was re - iterated to her by her solicitor on DATE and by counsel on DATE , following her receipt of the ORG report on DATE and the inquest . She was therefore unable to pursue any action which would have examined the liability of ORG custodians for failing to prevent him from killing himself in custody and which would have afforded the possibility of compensation in respect of his death .
The applicant lodged her application with ORG .
The duty to hold an inquest arises under LAW . Where there is reasonable cause to suspect that the deceased died in prison the coroner is obliged to hold an inquest together with a jury .

Inquest proceedings are directed solely to ascertaining the following limited matters : ( i ) who the deceased was ; ( ii ) how , when and where the deceased came by his death ( “ how ” meaning “ by what means ” as opposed to “ in what broad circumstances ” ) and ( iii ) the particulars required by the Registration Acts to be registered concerning the death ( LAW ) of the Coroner ’s LAW and rule CARDINAL of DATE , as interpreted by NORP v. GPE and GPE , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] QB CARDINAL ( “ ex parte PERSON ) ) .
ORG in ex parte PERSON defined the role of the coroner as follows at page CARDINAL :

“ It is the duty of the Coroner as the public official responsible for the conduct of inquests , whether he is sitting with a jury or without , to ensure that the relevant facts are fully , fairly and fearlessly investigated . He is bound to recognise the acute public concern rightly aroused where deaths occur in custody . He must ensure that the relevant facts are exposed to public scrutiny , particularly if there is evidence of foul play , abuse or inhumanity . ”
Rule CARDINAL of the Coroners Rules DATE provides :
“ No verdict shall be framed in such a way as to appear to determine any question of- ( a ) criminal liability on the part of a named person , or ( b ) civil liability . ”
Rule DATE was stated to express the following in ex parte PERSON at page CARDINAL :
“ It is not the function of a coroner or his jury to determine , or appear to determine , any question of criminal or civil liability , to apportion guilt or attribute blame . ”

In R ( on the application of PERSON and PERSON ) v. Secretary of ORG for ORG [ DATE ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL , ORG held that , in the light of the enactment of LAW DATE , which came into force in DATE and imposed a duty on NORP courts to act compatibly with rights set out in the LAW thereafter , in order to satisfy the investigative obligation under LAW it would be necessary , in an appropriate case , to permit a jury to return a verdict of “ system neglect ” in circumstances where , previously , domestic law , specifically ex parte PERSON , forbade such an outcome ( § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . ORG also held in that case that , where a death occurred in ORG custody , either at the hands of another prisoner or as a result of a suicide , the investigative obligation under LAW was engaged ( § MONEY ) .
Rule CARDINAL of the Coroners Rules DATE provides :

“ A coroner who believes that action should be taken to prevent the recurrence of fatalities similar to that in respect of which the inquest is being held may announce at the inquest that he is reporting the matter in writing to the person or authority who may have power to take such action and he may report the matter accordingly . ”
A coroner ’s court does not have jurisdiction to award compensation in respect of a death .
Pursuant to the common law , no one can recover damages in tort for the death of another .
LAW DATE confers a right of action for a wrongful act causing death . LAW ) provides :

“ If death is caused by any wrongful act , neglect or default which is such as would ( if death had not ensued ) have entitled the person injured to maintain an action and recover damages in respect thereof , the person who would have been liable if death had not ensued shall be liable to an action for damages , notwithstanding the death of the person injured . ”

The statutory right of action is however for the deceased ’s dependants ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) which allows the recovery of their pecuniary loss . If there is no dependency , there is no pecuniary loss to recover as damages . Bereavement damages ( fixed at MONEY ) are only available to the parents of a deceased child under DATE at the time of death or to the spouse of the deceased ( section CARDINALA(CARDINAL ) ) . Funeral expenses are recoverable ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
LAW ( Miscellaneous Provisions ) Act DATE provides for the survival of causes of action for the benefit of the deceased ’s personal estate . LAW ) provides as relevant :

“ Subject to the provisions of this section , on the death of any person after the commencement of this LAW all causes of action subsisting against or vested in him shall survive against , or , as the case may be , for the benefit of , his estate . ”

This enables recovery on behalf of the estate of damages for losses suffered by the deceased before he died , including any non - pecuniary loss such as damages for pain and suffering experienced between the infliction of injury and death . Where death is instantaneous or it can not be proved that the deceased experienced pain and suffering before death , damages are not recoverable under LAW and the only amount recoverable would be funeral expenses .

It was accepted in ORG case of PERSON v. Commissioner of ORG CARDINAL A.C. CARDINAL that there was a common law duty of care upon the police to take reasonable steps to prevent a person of sound mind who was known to be a suicide risk from taking his own life while in custody . The duty had been breached on the facts of the case when the deceased had been able to hang himself as a result of the officers having left the hatch of his cell door open . Liability for the death was shared equally with the deceased , as a result of his voluntary act .

In GPE v. the Chief Constable of GPE [ DATE ] CARDINAL WLR CARDINAL , ORG addressed the question , left open by ORG in PERSON , as to whether the duty under consideration in PERSON arose only where the authorities knew or ought to have known that the individual prisoner presented a suicide risk , or whether it was a duty owed to all prisoners in custody . ORG held that suicide was not a foreseeable risk in relation to every prisoner and that the obligation to take reasonable care to prevent a prisoner from taking his own life deliberately only arose where the custodian knew or ought to have known that the individual prisoner presented a suicide risk . It further held that the increased risk of suicide amongst prisoners gave rise to an obligation , within the general duty of care of the custodian for the health and safety of the prisoner , to take reasonable steps to identify whether or not a prisoner presented a suicide risk . As , on the facts , the police had been justified in concluding that the deceased was not a suicide risk , no duty of care was owed to him to prevent him from taking his own life and therefore it was not a breach of any duty to permit the deceased to retain his belt or to have placed the deceased in a cell in which the gate on the door , from which the deceased had hanged himself using his belt as a ligature , did not comply with recommendations contained in ORG circulars . As PERSON elected not to petition ORG for leave to appeal , the issue in GPE has not yet been addressed by ORG .

In ORG referred to the NORP case of PERSON v. PERSON ( DATE ) CARDINAL DLR ( CARDINALth ) CARDINAL , in which the allegations were that , although the deceased , a prisoner who had hanged himself , was not known to be a suicide risk , the standard procedures in the police operating manual should have been followed . ORG stated the following principle ( cited at page CARDINAL of Orange ) :

“ Suicide being reasonably foreseeable for prisoners as a group , and the defendants not having time to examine each person to see whether or not he is likely to attempt suicide , the reasonable course is to adopt a minimum standard applicable to all prisoners except those who require special attention . The steps outlined in an operating manual seem appropriate for that purpose . ”
ORG No . CARDINAL , dated DATE and implemented on DATE , introduced the ORG form and described its purpose as follows :

“ It is essential that those responsible for the custody and care of a detainee / prisoner are made fully aware at all times of any associated risks from the prisoner and/or of any medical or psychiatric conditions of the prisoner . To ensure that such information is recorded for each prisoner and therefore accessible to all police officers , prison officers or escort custody officers in whose custody the prisoner may be , a form has been introduced for national use by the police , prison , court and escort services . ...

... The PER form is designed for use by everyone who comes into custodial contact with prisoners and should help minimise the danger of relevant information about the prisoner not being passed on to receiving authorities and , importantly , to those officers who take over responsibility for prisoners from others . Correct use of the form should not only ensure that prisoners are given the correct level of care and attention at all stages but that those who have responsibility for custody and transfer are made aware of the risks or potential risks they may face . ”
Paragraph CARDINAL.CARDINAL of Code C of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act DATE provides :

“ If a detained person requests a medical examination the police surgeon must be called as soon as practicable . He may in addition be examined by a medical practitioner of his own choice at his own expense . ”
ORG No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , dated DATE , provides in relevant part :

“ Police authorities and police officers are aware of the need to ensure that fittings in cells should not provide opportunity for a prisoner to do himself injury ... Chief Constables are requested to arrange for early inspection of all police cells to ensure that there are no projections or fittings which prisoners might use to cause themselves injury . ...

... where cell doors are fitted with a drop - down service hatch , the hatch should not be left open when the cell is occupied by a prisoner . With the hatch open it would be possible for a person inside the cell to secure a ligature on the handle of the hatch . ”
Paragraph CARDINAL.CARDINAL of the PECS report , headed “ Area CARDINAL LOC ” stated , in relevant part , as follows :
“ ORG in LOC commenced on DATE with a phased introduction DATE . It provides court escort and custody services across the CARDINAL counties of GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE .

The contract in DATE has been fully operational for DATE . The contractor is ORG . In DATE of the contract operation , Group CARDINAL has undertaken an average of CARDINAL prisoner movements and handled an average of CARDINAL prisoners . During this period the contractor has been faced with numerous incidents , including attempted suicide and self - harm . The number of attempted suicides / self - harm incidents recorded in DATE is illustrated in the table below :

The nature of these incidents varies considerably , ranging from a determined attempt where a prisoner swallowed medication which had previously been concealed about the person , to smaller incidents where individual prisoners have struck hard surfaces causing minor injuries to their hands or grazes to their heads . The contractor has , however , always taken each incident seriously . One has to be cautious given the vulnerable nature of some prisoners , particularly those on remand or appearing at court for the first time . ORG has a very good record of prisoner care . ”
